questions.text: Based on the symptoms reported by the patient, what could be the possible diagnosis for a 30-year-old man who has been experiencing recurrent discharge and pain due to lesions around the anus for the past four years? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Fistula in ano

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A fistula in ano is an abnormal tract that typically develops between the anal canal and the perianal skin, usually due to a previously untreated or inadequately treated abscess. The chronic and recurrent nature of symptoms like discharge and pain around the anus is a hallmark of this condition.
  • ➤ A fistula in ano is an abnormal tract that typically develops between the anal canal and the perianal skin, usually due to a previously untreated or inadequately treated abscess.
  • ➤ The chronic and recurrent nature of symptoms like discharge and pain around the anus is a hallmark of this condition.

questions.text: A patient presents after 5 days of unprotected intercourse for emergency contraception. What is the method of choice? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) IUCD

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) is the preferred method for emergency contraception if presented within 120 hours (5 days) of unprotected intercourse. The IUCD is highly effective and provides long-term contraception, which makes it suitable for women seeking ongoing birth control.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Misoprostol: This is not used for emergency contraception; it is typically used for medical termination of pregnancy.
  • • Option A. Misoprostol:
  • • Option B. Levonorgestrel: Although effective as emergency contraception, it is most efficacious within 72 hours (3 days) of unprotected intercourse.
  • • Option B. Levonorgestrel:
  • • Option D. Combined OCP: The Yuzpe regimen, which uses a high dose of combined oral contraceptive pills, is also most effective within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse.
  • • Option D. Combined OCP:
  • • Additionally, another option not mentioned in the question is ulipristal acetate, a selective progesterone receptor modulator, which can be used up to 120 hours (5 days) after unprotected intercourse. However, it is not available in India.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) is the method of choice for emergency contraception if presented within 120 hours (5 days) of unprotected intercourse, offering both immediate and long-term contraception.

questions.text: Bilateral pedal edema is least likely to be associated with which of the following? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic venous insufficiency is least likely to be associated with bilateral pedal edema compared to chronic renal failure, congestive heart failure, and chronic liver disease.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy was brought to OPD with complaint of painless lump in left knee. X-ray is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Osteochondroma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Osteochondromas are developmental malformations rather than true neoplasms that are usually painless. The pain can be due to bursitis (most common). The physical finding is usually a palpable mass.
  • ➤ Osteochondromas are developmental malformations rather than true neoplasms that are usually painless.
  • ➤ The pain can be due to bursitis (most common).
  • ➤ The physical finding is usually a palpable mass.

questions.text: Identify the organism from the lifecycle shown in the image given below? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Toxoplasma gondii

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Toxoplasma gondii is an obligate intracellular parasite with a complex lifecycle involving cats as definitive hosts and various animals, including humans, as intermediate hosts. The lifecycle stages, including oocysts and tissue cysts, are crucial for transmission and infection.

questions.text: Mark the correct statement regarding inflammatory bowel disease (IBD): ( INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Skepletions are present in Crohn's disease

options.label: B
options.text: Mucosal layers are involved in Crohn's disease and transmural involvement is seen in ulcerative colitis

options.label: C
options.text: Inflammatory bowel disease has a strong genetic predisposition

options.label: D
options.text: Crohn's disease is curable through surgical resection of the affected segment

questions.correct_answer: A. Skepletions are present in Crohn's disease
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Skepletions (skip lesions) are a characteristic feature of Crohn's disease, distinguishing it from ulcerative colitis

questions.text: A patient with suspected tuberculosis underwent CBNAAT testing and is started on HRZE. CBNAAT is helpful for which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) MTB + Rifampicin resistance

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Cartridge-based nucleic acid amplification test (CBNAAT) is a rapid molecular test for the detection of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB) and resistance to rifampicin (RIF).
  • • It is highly effective for diagnosing tuberculosis and determining rifampicin resistance by detecting mutations in the rpoB gene , which is associated with rifampicin resistance. This allows for quick initiation of appropriate therapy, especially important in cases of drug-resistant TB
  • • rpoB gene
  • • MTB Detection : CBNAAT can confirm the presence of Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Rifampicin Resistance : By identifying rpoB gene mutations, CBNAAT can detect rifampicin resistance, which is a critical factor in managing and treating TB.
  • • MTB Detection : CBNAAT can confirm the presence of Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • • MTB Detection
  • • Rifampicin Resistance : By identifying rpoB gene mutations, CBNAAT can detect rifampicin resistance, which is a critical factor in managing and treating TB.
  • • Rifampicin Resistance
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A. Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB) : While CBNAAT detects MTB, it also provides crucial information about rifampicin resistance, making option B more accurate.
  • • Option A. Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB)
  • • Option C. MTB + Isoniazid resistance : CBNAAT does not detect isoniazid resistance directly.
  • • Option C. MTB + Isoniazid resistance
  • • Option D. MTB + Ethambutol and Rifampicin : CBNAAT does not provide information about ethambutol resistance.
  • • Option D. MTB + Ethambutol and Rifampicin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objectives:
  • ➤ CBNAAT is a rapid and effective test for detecting Mycobacterium tuberculosis and rifampicin resistance by identifying mutations in the rpoB gene.

questions.text: Lagophthalmos is caused by defect in: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 7th cranial nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lagophthalmos is caused by a defect in the 7th cranial nerve (facial nerve), which innervates the orbicularis oculi muscle responsible for eyelid closure

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH)? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Urinary sodium <20 mEq/L

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key fact to remember is that in SIADH, patients have high urinary sodium (typically >40 mEq/L) due to the body's inability to excrete water properly, leading to concentrated urine.
  • ➤ high urinary sodium (typically >40 mEq/L)

questions.text: Which of the following is a primary lymphoid organ? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The thymus is a primary lymphoid organ where T cells mature, playing a crucial role in the development of the immune system.
  • ➤ Spleen, lymph node and tonsils are considered as secondary lymphoid organs
  • ➤ Bone marrow has been considered as an example of both a primary as well as a secondary lymphoid organ.

questions.text: The marked structure secretes which hormone? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The adrenal medulla, the innermost part of the adrenal gland, is responsible for secreting adrenaline, a hormone essential for the body's acute stress response.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with a history of recurrent bacterial and fungal infections, particularly involving the skin and respiratory tract. The patient's parents report that he has had multiple abscesses and lymphadenitis. Dihydrorhodamine (DHR) test results show an abnormal pattern. What is the primary suspicion based on these findings? ( FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Chronic granulomatous disease

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The clinical presentation of recurrent bacterial and fungal infections, particularly involving the skin and respiratory tract, along with a history of multiple abscesses and lymphadenitis in a young child, strongly suggests a primary immunodeficiency disorder. The abnormal dihydrorhodamine (DHR) test result further supports the diagnosis of chronic granulomatous disease (CGD).
  • • CGD is a rare inherited disorder characterized by defective oxygen-dependent killing of microorganisms by phagocytic cells, such as neutrophils and macrophages. This defect is caused by mutations in the genes encoding components of the NADPH oxidase enzyme complex , which is responsible for generating reactive oxygen species (ROS) necessary for microbial killing. The inability to produce sufficient ROS leads to recurrent infections, especially with catalase-positive organisms.
  • • genes encoding components of the NADPH oxidase enzyme complex
  • • The DHR test is a flow cytometry-based assay that measures the production of ROS by neutrophils after stimulation. An abnormal DHR test result, as seen in this patient, is consistent with the diagnosis of CGD.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Severe combined immunodeficiency disease (SCID) is a group of disorders characterized by defects in both cellular and humoral immunity.
  • • Option B.
  • • X-linked SCID is an X-linked recessive immunodeficiency disorder characterized by chronic diarrhea, periodic respiratory infection, and acquired maternal T cell-mediated GVHD. Mutations in interleukin-2 receptor gamma (IL2RG) can result in X-SCID. While patients with SCID are also susceptible to recurrent infections, the presentation typically involves opportunistic infections and failure to thrive, which are not mentioned in this case.
  • • interleukin-2
  • • Option C. Sialyl Lewis X defect, also known as leukocyte adhesion deficiency type 2 (LAD-2), is a rare disorder characterized by defective leukocyte rolling and adhesion due to a deficiency in the sialyl Lewis X ligand . While patients with LAD-2 may present with recurrent infections, the DHR test would not be abnormal in this condition.
  • • Option C.
  • • as leukocyte adhesion deficiency type 2 (LAD-2),
  • • the sialyl Lewis X ligand
  • • Option D. Integrin defects, such as leukocyte adhesion deficiency type 1 (LAD-1), are characterized by defective leukocyte adhesion and migration due to mutations in the genes encoding integrins. Although patients with LAD-1 may present with recurrent infections, the DHR test would not be abnormal in this condition.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic granulomatous disease should be suspected in a child presenting with recurrent bacterial and fungal infections, particularly involving the skin and respiratory tract, along with a history of multiple abscesses and lymphadenitis, and an abnormal DHR test result.

questions.text: Identify the organism shown in this image: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Ascaris lumbricoides

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ascaris lumbricoides is a large, cylindrical nematode parasite found in the human intestine, easily identifiable by its size, tapered ends, and characteristic pink to white color transition. The disease it causes, ascariasis, is transmitted via the fecal-oral route.

questions.text: Hamman sign is seen in: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans.  C) Pneumomediastinum

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hamman sign, or Hamman's crunch, is a specific clinical sign heard in cases of pneumomediastinum, characterized by a crunching sound synchronous with the heartbeat due to the presence of air in the mediastinum.

Educational Objective:

A urine sample is taken, and a culture is performed, which reveals the presence of a common organism associated with acute bacterial prostatitis. Identify the organism?(NEET PG 2018)

questions.text: Following is the x-ray of an 18-year-old boy who complains of fever, pain in the lower limb, local rise of temperature, and tenderness in the area shown. On investigation, he has increased ESR. What can be the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:

options.label: B

questions.text: Which of the subsequent options is non-essential in the evaluation of mosaic Turner syndrome? ( INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Anti-nuclear antibodies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While glucose tolerance testing, audiometry, and echocardiography are essential in the evaluation of Turner syndrome, testing for anti-nuclear antibodies is not necessary unless there is a clinical suspicion of an associated autoimmune disorder.

questions.text: A 53-year-old gentleman presents with chest pain which is happening at rest. Pain is persistent for 3-5 minutes and he is having recurrent pain over the last 48 hours and he used 3 puffs of GTN to relieve his pain. His current medications include GTN PRN, Atorvastatin 20mg HS, Metoprolol 50mg BID, and Aspirin 75mg OD. His troponin was negative and ECG showed LVH with flattening of the ST segment. What is the most appropriate next step in management? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Start enoxaparin 1mg/kg s.c BD

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with high-risk unstable angina, especially those with recurrent chest pain at rest and ECG changes, initiating therapeutic anticoagulation with enoxaparin is a critical step in the acute management to prevent thrombus formation and progression to myocardial infarction.

options.label: C

Ans. C) Doing EEG is mandatory for the diagnosis of seizures.

questions.text: Which hormones are produced from these zones? (INICET MAY 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: A - Cortisol B - Aldosterone C - Androgens D - Epinephrine

options.label: B
options.text: A - Aldosterone B - Cortisol C - Androgens D - Epinephrine

options.label: C
options.text: A - Epinephrine B - Cortisol C - Aldosterone D - Androgens

options.label: D
options.text: A - Aldosterone B - Epinephrine C - Androgens D - Cortisol

questions.correct_answer: B. A - Aldosterone B - Cortisol C - Androgens D - Epinephrine
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) A - Aldosterone B - Cortisol C - Androgens D - Epinephrine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The adrenal gland, located on top of the kidneys, consists of the adrenal cortex and the adrenal medulla. The cortex is further divided into three zones: the zona glomerulosa, zona fasciculata, and zona reticularis. These zones are responsible for producing different types of hormones, remembered by the mnemonic "GFR."
  • • mnemonic "GFR."
  • • Zona Glomerulosa (A): This outermost layer is responsible for producing mineralocorticoids, the most important being Aldosterone . Aldosterone plays a critical role in regulating sodium and potassium balance in the body. Zona Fasciculata (B): The middle layer produces glucocorticoids, primarily Cortisol . Cortisol is involved in stress response, metabolism regulation, and immune function. Zona Reticularis (C): The innermost cortical layer produces androgens, specifically DHEA (Dehydroepiandrosterone) , which is a precursor to sex steroids like testosterone and estrogen. Adrenal Medulla (D): The medulla produces catecholamines, primarily Epinephrine (adrenaline) , which is crucial for the fight-or-flight response.
  • • Zona Glomerulosa (A): This outermost layer is responsible for producing mineralocorticoids, the most important being Aldosterone . Aldosterone plays a critical role in regulating sodium and potassium balance in the body.
  • • Zona Glomerulosa (A):
  • • Aldosterone
  • • Zona Fasciculata (B): The middle layer produces glucocorticoids, primarily Cortisol . Cortisol is involved in stress response, metabolism regulation, and immune function.
  • • Zona Fasciculata (B):
  • • Cortisol
  • • Zona Reticularis (C): The innermost cortical layer produces androgens, specifically DHEA (Dehydroepiandrosterone) , which is a precursor to sex steroids like testosterone and estrogen.
  • • Zona Reticularis (C):
  • • DHEA (Dehydroepiandrosterone)
  • • Adrenal Medulla (D): The medulla produces catecholamines, primarily Epinephrine (adrenaline) , which is crucial for the fight-or-flight response.
  • • Adrenal Medulla (D):
  • • Epinephrine (adrenaline)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The adrenal cortex is divided into three zones—zona glomerulosa, zona fasciculata, and zona reticularis—which produce aldosterone, cortisol, and androgens, respectively. The adrenal medulla produces catecholamines, primarily epinephrine

questions.text: Mr. Seth recently underwent surgery to remove a parathyroid gland due to hyperparathyroidism. The surgeon informed the patient that one or more of the parathyroid glands may be transferred to another location during the surgery to protect them or due to their location. The parathyroid is commonly transferred to? ( NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Brachioradialis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The most common site for the relocation of the parathyroid gland(s) is in the forearm muscle, specifically the nondominant side brachioradialis. Transplantation to this location provides several advantages:
  • • Accessibility : The forearm location is easily accessible for potential future surgical interventions if necessary. Monitoring : This location allows for straightforward monitoring of parathyroid function using simple clinical tests. Functionality : The transplanted gland(s) will continue to produce parathyroid hormone normally, aiding in the regulation of calcium levels in the body. Ease of Removal : If there is disease recurrence after surgery, the forearm location facilitates easy removal. Typically, a total of 12 to 14 pieces are transplanted in a type of heterotopic transplant.
  • • Accessibility : The forearm location is easily accessible for potential future surgical interventions if necessary.
  • • Accessibility
  • • Monitoring : This location allows for straightforward monitoring of parathyroid function using simple clinical tests.
  • • Monitoring
  • • Functionality : The transplanted gland(s) will continue to produce parathyroid hormone normally, aiding in the regulation of calcium levels in the body.
  • • Functionality
  • • Ease of Removal : If there is disease recurrence after surgery, the forearm location facilitates easy removal.
  • • Ease of Removal
  • • Typically, a total of 12 to 14 pieces are transplanted in a type of heterotopic transplant.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Triceps: Triceps is not a preferred site for parathyroid transplantation due to less accessibility and monitoring challenges compared to the brachioradialis.
  • • Option A. Triceps:
  • • Option B. Biceps: Biceps is also not commonly used for parathyroid transplantation because it does not offer the same ease of access and monitoring advantages as the brachioradialis.
  • • Option B. Biceps:
  • • Option C. Sartorius: Sartorius is not a preferred site for parathyroid transplantation. The forearm muscle (brachioradialis) is favored for its convenience and monitoring benefits.
  • • Option C. Sartorius:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The brachioradialis muscle in the forearm is the most common site for parathyroid gland relocation during surgery due to its ease of access, convenient monitoring, and straightforward removal if needed.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs reduce mortality in a patient with heart failure? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Beta-blockers, such as metoprolol succinate , are essential in reducing mortality in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction

  • ➤ ARNIs (Angiotensin Receptor-Neprilysin Inhibitors) : Examples: Sacubitril/Valsartan Currently the first-line treatment, considered superior to ACE inhibitors and ARBs when available. ACE Inhibitors (Angiotensin-Converting Enzyme inhibitors) and ARBs (Angiotensin II Receptor Blockers) : Considered equally effective in efficacy; used when ARNIs are not available. Beta Blockers : Specific agents highlighted: Metoprolol, Bisoprolol, and Carvedilol. MRS (Mineralocorticoid Receptor Antagonists) : Examples: Spironolactone and Eplerenone. SGLT2 Inhibitors (Sodium-Glucose Cotransporter 2 inhibitors) : Emerging class of drugs also showing benefits in heart failure management. Hydralazine and Isosorbide Dinitrate (HISDN) : Noted specifically for proven benefits in African American patients with heart failure.

  • ➤ Including loop and thiazide diuretics, noted to not improve survival but are used primarily for symptom management and fluid regulation.
  • ➤ Calcium Channel Blockers and Nitrates : Mentioned as not improving survival in heart failure, particularly in patients with reduced ejection fraction.
  • ➤ Calcium Channel Blockers and Nitrates
  • ➤ Mentioned as not improving survival in heart failure, particularly in patients with reduced ejection fraction.
  • ➤ Mentioned as not improving survival in heart failure, particularly in patients with reduced ejection fraction.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.correct_answer: C. Deficiency of CD 55 and CD 59
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Deficiency of CD 55 and CD 59

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The true hallmark of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria is the deficiency of CD55 and CD59 on the surface of blood cells, leading to increased vulnerability to lysis by the complement system and resulting in intravascular hemolysis. This understanding is critical for the correct diagnosis and management of PNH.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison/PNH/Chapter 100

questions.text: Which of the following type of cataract is seen in ocular blunt trauma?( FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Rosette cataract

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Rosette cataract is commonly seen in ocular blunt trauma.

questions.text: All are true about biophysical profile (BPP) except? (INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Includes breathing, movements, tone, and AFI

options.label: B
options.text: Can tell us about fetal outcome and fetal pH

options.label: C
options.text: Score is inconsistent with fetal pH at different gestational ages

options.label: D
options.text: Score <4: fetal pH <7.2; Score 0: 100% fetal acidemia

questions.correct_answer: C. Score is inconsistent with fetal pH at different gestational ages
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Score is inconsistent with fetal pH at different gestational ages

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • BPP score is not inconsistent with fetal pH, but has a direct linear relationship with fetal pH and thus can be used to predict fetal acidemia. BPP is a multi-parametric, screening test to assess uteroplacental insufficiency. It consists of five components/ variables and the observations are made in a 30 minutes time period. The Biophysical Profile has 5 components and is scored using Manning score NST Amniotic Fluid Volume Fetal movement Fetal Tone Fetal Breathing
  • • BPP score is not inconsistent with fetal pH, but has a direct linear relationship with fetal pH and thus can be used to predict fetal acidemia.
  • • BPP is a multi-parametric, screening test to assess uteroplacental insufficiency.
  • • It consists of five components/ variables and the observations are made in a 30 minutes time period.
  • • The Biophysical Profile has 5 components and is scored using Manning score NST Amniotic Fluid Volume Fetal movement Fetal Tone Fetal Breathing
  • • NST Amniotic Fluid Volume Fetal movement Fetal Tone Fetal Breathing
  • • NST
  • • Amniotic Fluid Volume
  • • Fetal movement
  • • Fetal Tone
  • • Fetal Breathing
  • • A low Manning score correlates with fetal hypoxia Narcotics and sedatives can significantly lower the score A BPP score of 0 was almost invariably associated with significant fetal acidemia, whereas a normal score of 8 or 10 was associated with normal pH. An equivocal test result—a score of 6—was a poor predictor of an abnormal outcome. A drop in the BPP score from 2 or 4 down to 0 more accurately predicted an abnormal fetal outcome. Overall, BPP scores provided poor sensitivity to predict cord blood pH The Modified BPP has 2 components NST AFI
  • • A low Manning score correlates with fetal hypoxia
  • • Narcotics and sedatives can significantly lower the score
  • • A BPP score of 0 was almost invariably associated with significant fetal acidemia, whereas a normal score of 8 or 10 was associated with normal pH.
  • • An equivocal test result—a score of 6—was a poor predictor of an abnormal outcome. A drop in the BPP score from 2 or 4 down to 0 more accurately predicted an abnormal fetal outcome.
  • • Overall, BPP scores provided poor sensitivity to predict cord blood pH
  • • The Modified BPP has 2 components
  • • NST
  • • NST
  • • AFI
  • • AFI
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Includes breathing, movements, tone, and AFI : This statement is true. The BPP includes assessments of fetal breathing, movements, tone, and the amniotic fluid index (AFI) as part of its evaluation.
  • • Option A. Includes breathing, movements, tone, and AFI
  • • Option B. Can tell us about fetal outcome and fetal pH : This statement is true. The BPP score helps predict fetal outcome and provides an indication of fetal pH, reflecting the level of fetal distress.
  • • Option B. Can tell us about fetal outcome and fetal pH
  • • Option D. Score <4: fetal pH <7.2; Score 0: 100% fetal acidemia : This statement is true. A BPP score of less than 4 correlates with a fetal pH <7.2, and a score of 0 is almost invariably associated with significant fetal acidemia.
  • • Option D. Score <4: fetal pH <7.2; Score 0: 100% fetal acidemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Biophysical Profile (BPP) provides a consistent prediction of fetal pH and outcome, with a lower score correlating with increased risk of fetal acidemia.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 999, Williams Obstetric 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 999, Williams Obstetric 26 th edition

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with an episode of acute onset dizziness and loss of consciousness which lasted for a few seconds followed by a regain of full consciousness. There were no similar episodes in the past. Which of the following is a true statement regarding this scenario? (NEET PG 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: ECG to rule out atrial fibrillation

options.label: B
options.text: If ECG is normal, CT scan should be done

options.label: D
options.text: Vestibular neuritis is a possible condition that can cause these symptoms

questions.correct_answer: A. ECG to rule out atrial fibrillation
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. ECG to rule out atrial fibrillation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In elderly patients presenting with an acute onset of dizziness and syncope, an ECG is an essential first step to rule out arrhythmic causes such as atrial fibrillation. Additional diagnostic steps should be guided by the findings of the initial evaluation and specific clinical indicators.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison 21/Atrial fibrillation/Chap 251

questions.text: In a patient with suspected endocrine dysfunction, which hormone primarily acts through the signaling pathway shown in the diagram below, potentially contributing to the patient's condition? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Leptin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Saturnine gout is seen in: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Lead poisoning

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Saturnine gout is a specific type of gout caused by chronic lead poisoning, characterized by hyperuricemia and tubulointerstitial renal damage.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding accommodative esotropia? ( NEET PG 2019)

options.label: A
options.text: It is the most common type of squint.

options.label: B
options.text: Miotics are used as the treatment strategy in the high AC/A ratio.

options.label: C
options.text: It is associated with high myopia.

options.label: D
options.text: Refractive type can be fully corrected by use of spectacles.

questions.correct_answer: C. It is associated with high myopia.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. It is associated with high myopia.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Accommodative esotropia, the most common type of squint, is associated with high hypermetropia and can often be fully corrected by spectacles. It is not associated with high myopia. Different treatment strategies, including the use of spectacles and bifocals, depend on the specific type and underlying cause of the esotropia.

questions.text: Fallen fragment sign is characteristic of:(NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Simple bone cyst

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fallen fragment sign is seen in simple (unicameral) bone cyst. It is a thinned cortical fragment that fractures and falls into the base of the lesion, confirming its empty cystic nature

questions.text: Which of the following adverse effect is least likely to be associated with the use of amiodarone? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Gynecomastia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gynecomastia is typically associated with drugs that affect hormonal balance. Drugs causing gynecomastia includes:
  • ➤ Drugs causing gynecomastia includes:
  • ➤ DI: DI goxin
  • ➤ DI: DI
  • ➤ S: S pironolactone
  • ➤ S: S
  • ➤ C: C imetidine
  • ➤ C: C
  • ➤ O: O estrogens
  • ➤ O: O

questions.text: Sudden loss of vision without fundal glow without history of trauma is caused by: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Vitreous hemorrhage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sudden loss of vision combined with absence of fundal glow, without a history of trauma, is highly characteristic of vitreous hemorrhage. This condition requires prompt evaluation to determine the underlying cause, which could include proliferative diabetic retinopathy, Eales disease, central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO), or other vascular abnormalities of the retina
